skill.name: webapp-testing
skill.description: Toolkit for interacting with and testing local web applications using Playwright. Supports verifying frontend functionality, debugging UI behavior, capturing browser screenshots, and viewing browser logs.
skill.summary: Toolkit for interacting with and testing local web applications using Playwright. Supports verifying...
skill.author: DYAI2025

security_audit.summary: Legitimate web testing toolkit using Playwright. All static findings are false positives. URLs flagged are localhost test addresses, subprocess calls are for local dev server management, and 'weak crypto' detections are scanner errors on license text and argparse definitions. No network exfiltration, credential access, or persistence mechanisms.

content.value_statement: Testing web applications manually takes time and introduces errors. This skill provides Playwright automation scripts and server management tools to verify frontend functionality, capture screenshots, debug UI behavior, and view browser console logs.
actual_capabilities: Launch Chromium browser in headless mode for automated testing
Start and manage local development servers automatically
Capture full-page screenshots of web applications
Discover and inspect DOM elements like buttons, links, and inputs
Wait for networkidle state before interacting with dynamic pages
Capture and save browser console logs to files
limitations: Only supports Chromium browser for automation
Requires Playwright and Python to be installed
Cannot test applications requiring authentication unless credentials provided in scripts
Designed for local development environments only

use_cases.title: Automate UI regression testing
use_cases.description: Create Playwright scripts to verify UI components render correctly and interactions work as expected.

use_cases.title: Capture bug reproduction screenshots
use_cases.description: Navigate to application states and capture screenshots and console logs to document issues.

use_cases.title: Test full-stack applications
use_cases.description: Manage backend and frontend servers together to run end-to-end tests on complete applications.

prompt_templates.title: Basic page screenshot
prompt_templates.scenario: Capture a screenshot of a local web page
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Playwright script to navigate to http://localhost:5173, wait for networkidle, and save a full-page screenshot to /tmp/page.png

prompt_templates.title: Element discovery
prompt_templates.scenario: Find interactive elements on a page
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a script that discovers all buttons, links, and input fields on http://localhost:3000 and prints their text content and attributes

prompt_templates.title: Server plus test
prompt_templates.prompt: Use scripts/with_server.py to start a dev server on port 5173, then run a Playwright script that clicks the submit button and captures console output

prompt_templates.title: Multi-server testing
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a command using with_server.py that starts both a Python backend on port 3000 and npm frontend on port 5173, then runs an automation script

output_examples.input: Test the login page of my local React app running on port 5173
output: Starting Chromium and navigating to http://localhost:5173
Waiting for networkidle - page fully loaded
Found 3 input fields: username, password, remember
Found 2 buttons: Sign In, Forgot Password
Console logs captured: 12 messages (3 warnings, 0 errors)

best_practices: Always wait for networkidle before inspecting dynamic web applications
Use the with_server.py helper to manage server lifecycle automatically
Run scripts with --help first to understand available options before modifying
anti_patterns: Do not inspect DOM before networkidle on SPAs - content may not be rendered yet
Do not hardcode credentials in scripts - use environment variables instead
Do not forget to close the browser when done - resources may leak

faq.question: Which browsers are supported?
faq.answer: This skill uses Chromium exclusively for headless testing. Other browsers require configuration changes.

faq.question: Can I test authenticated pages?
faq.answer: Yes, but you must handle login within your script or use existing authenticated browser sessions.

faq.question: How do I test pages behind authentication?
faq.answer: Include login steps in your Playwright script, or use storageState to load saved session cookies.

faq.question: Is my data safe when running these scripts?
faq.answer: Yes, all scripts run locally. No data is sent to external servers. Screenshots save to local paths only.

faq.question: Why is my page empty when I inspect it?
faq.answer: You likely did not wait for networkidle. Add page.wait_for_load_state('networkidle') before inspection.

faq.question: How is this different from Selenium or Cypress?
faq.answer: Playwright offers faster execution, better async handling, and built-in auto-waiting compared to older tools.
